case_title: Mst. SHARAM KHATOON vs HAZOOR DIN And Other

accussed_details.name: Hazoor Din
allegation: Sale of land without pre-emption rights

accussed_details.name: Ali Muhammad
allegation: Purchase of land without pre-emption rights

accussed_details.name: Muhammad Abdullah
allegation: Purchase of land without pre-emption rights

complaint_summary: The plaintiff, Mst. Sharam Khatoon, filed a suit for possession of land sold by her father, Hazoor Din, to the defendants, claiming a superior right of pre-emption as the vendor's daughter.
investigation_summary: The defendants argued that the sale was sanctioned by the Deputy Commissioner under Section 3(2) of the Punjab Land Alienation Act of 1900, making the land immune from pre-emption under Section 9 of the Punjab Pre-emption Act of 1913.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the appeal, holding that Section 9 of the Punjab Pre-emption Act repealed conflicting provisions of Section 5 of the Punjab Land Alienation Act. It also ruled that Section 75 of the Interim Constitution Act of 1952 preserved the validity of the Land Alienation Act.

plaintiff_arguments: Section 9 of the Punjab Pre-emption Act of 1913 does not repeal Section 5 of the Punjab Land Alienation Act of 1900.
Improper enquiry by Deputy Commissioner before sanctioning sale under Section 3(2) of the Punjab Land Alienation Act.
Section 72 of the Interim Constitution Act 1952 of Bahawalpur renders the Land Alienation Act of 1900 inoperative and void.
defendant_arguments: Sale sanctioned by Deputy Commissioner under Section 3(2) of the Punjab Land Alienation Act of 1900.
Land not pre-emptiable under Section 9 of the Punjab Pre-emption Act.

sections: Section 3(2) of the Punjab Land Alienation Act of 1900
Section 9 of the Punjab Pre-emption Act of 1913
Section 72 of the Interim Constitution Act of 1952
Section 75 of the Interim Constitution Act of 1952
citations: Unreported ruling of High Court dated 1952-10-27
key_issues: Whether Section 9 of the Punjab Pre-emption Act repeals Section 5 of the Punjab Land Alienation Act.
Whether the Deputy Commissioner's sanctioning of the sale bars pre-emption claims.
Whether Section 72 of the Interim Constitution Act invalidates the Land Alienation Act.

court_findings.section_9_pre_emption_act: Explicitly bars pre-emption for sales sanctioned under Section 3(2) of the Punjab Land Alienation Act.
court_findings.section_21_land_alienation_act: Debars Civil Courts from questioning Deputy Commissioner's exercise of powers under the Act.
court_findings.section_72_interim_constitution_act: Prohibition clause does not invalidate the Land Alienation Act due to Section 75 of the Interim Constitution Act, which preserves prior laws.

legal_precedents.finding: Section 9 of the Pre-emption Act repeals conflicting provisions of Section 5 of the Punjab Land Alienation Act.

legal_precedents.citation: Unreported ruling of High Court dated 1952-10-27
legal_precedents.finding: Civil Courts lack jurisdiction over matters decided by Revenue Officers under the Punjab Land Alienation Act.

decision.reasoning: Sale sanctioned under Section 3(2) of the Punjab Land Alienation Act is immune from pre-emption under Section 9 of the Pre-emption Act. Land Alienation Act remains valid under Section 75 of the Interim Constitution Act.
decision.costs: Parties to bear their own costs.

legal_terms.Pre-emption: The right to purchase property before others.

words_and_phrases.Repugnant: Inconsistent or conflicting with another provision.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around pre-emption rights under conflicting statutes. The court upheld the validity of the Land Alienation Act, dismissing the plaintiff's appeal.

facts.claim_basis: Plaintiff claimed superior right of pre-emption as daughter of the vendor.
